qti-choice-interaction.qti-prompt: Which statement describes trade in Era 3 (6,000 BCE to 700 CE)?
qti-choice-interaction.qti-simple-choice: Societies in Era 3 participated in regional trade networks. This is correct. Neighboring societies exchanged with one another regionally. Two of the largest trade networks of this era were in Afro-Eurasia and Mesoamerica, but smaller networks existed in almost all areas of the world.
Societies in Era 3 participated in global trade networks. While you are right that societies did eventually participate in global trade, this phenomenon did not occur until Era 5 in the 1400s.
Societies in Era 3 participated in local trade only. Trade networks expanded as neighboring societies became more interconnected during Era 3.
Societies in Era 3 did not trade. Oops! That's not quite right, but smaller trade networks did expand significantly as societies became more interconnected during Era 3.

qti-content-body.p: Correct! During Era 3 (6,000 BCE to 700 CE), societies participated in regional trade networks. Major networks emerged in Afro-Eurasia and Mesoamerica, connecting neighboring societies but not yet spanning the globe.

Not quite. Think about the scale of trade during this early era. While trade was expanding beyond purely local exchanges, it had not yet reached a global scale. Regional networks connected neighboring societies, particularly in Afro-Eurasia and Mesoamerica.
